title: Fast Hybrid Network Algorithms for Shortest Paths in Sparse Graphs

In , the authors give a lower bound of Î©~â€‹(n1/3)~Î©superscriptğ‘›13\widetilde{\Omega}(n^{1/3}) rounds for computing the diameter in arbitrary graphs in our model.
They also give approximation algorithms with approximation factors (3/2+Îµ)32ğœ€(3/2+\varepsilon) and (1+Îµ)1ğœ€(1+\varepsilon) that run in time O~â€‹(n1/3/Îµ)~ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›13ğœ€\widetilde{O}(n^{1/3}/\varepsilon) and O~â€‹(n0.397/Îµ)~ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›0.397ğœ€\widetilde{O}(n^{0.397}/\varepsilon), respectively.
Even though APSP and the diameter problem are closely related, we demonstrate that the diameter can be computed much faster in our hybrid network model for certain graphs classes. As already pointed out, the global network in our model has a close connection to overlay networks.
The NCC model, which has been introduced in [ref]7, mainly focuses on the impact of node capacities, especially when the nodes have a high degree.
Since, intuitively, for many graph problems the existence of each edge is relevant for the output, most algorithms in [ref]7 depend on the arboricity ağ‘a of GğºG (which is, roughly speaking, the time needed to efficiently distribute the load of all edges over the network).
The authors present O~â€‹(a)~ğ‘‚ğ‘\widetilde{O}(a) algorithms for local problems such as MIS, matching, or coloring, an O~â€‹(D+a)~ğ‘‚ğ·ğ‘\widetilde{O}(D+a) algorithm for BFS tree, and an O~â€‹(1)~ğ‘‚1\widetilde{O}(1) algorithm to compute a minimum spanning tree (MST).
Recently, O~â€‹(Î”)~ğ‘‚Î”\widetilde{O}(\Delta)-time algorithms for graph realization problems have been presented [ref]6, where Î”Î”\Delta is the maximum node degree; notably, most of the algorithms work in the NCC0 variant.
Furthermore, Robinson  investigates the information the nodes need to learn to jointly solve graph problems and derives a lower bound for constructing spanners in the NCC.
For example, his result implies that spanners with constant stretch require polynomial time in the NCC, and are therefore harder to compute than MSTs.
Since our global network behaves like an overlay network, we can make efficient use of the so-called shortest-path diameter reduction technique .
By adding shortcuts between nodes in the global network, we can bridge large distances quickly throughout our computations. Our work also relates to the literature concerned with overlay construction     4 5, where the goal is to transform a low-degree weakly-connected graph into a low-depth overlay network such as a binary tree using node introductions.
Recently, 5 showed a randomized Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n) time overlay construction algorithm for the NCC0 model, if the initial degree is constant.
Our algorithms directly yield a deterministic Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n) time alternative for pseudotrees.
It may be interesting to see whether our results can be used to compute deterministic overlay construction algorithms for sparse graphs. A problem closely related to SSSP is the computation of short routing paths between any given nodes.
The problem has, for example, been studied in mobile ad-hoc networks 9, in which constant-competitive routing paths can be computed in Oâ€‹(log2â¡n)ğ‘‚superscript2ğ‘›O(\log^{2}n) rounds 5.
The authors consider a hybrid network model similar to , where nodes can communicate using either their WiFi-interface (similar to the local edges) or the cellular infrastructure (similar to global edges). In the classical CONGEST model there is a lower bound of Î©~â€‹(n+D)~Î©ğ‘›ğ·\widetilde{\Omega}(\sqrt{n}+D) rounds to approximate SSSP with a constant factorÂ .
This bound is tight, as there is a (1+Îµ)1ğœ€(1+\varepsilon)-approximation algorithm by Becker et al. that runs in O~â€‹(n+D)~ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ·\widetilde{O}(\sqrt{n}+D) roundsÂ .
The best known algorithms for computing exact SSSP in the CONGEST model are the ones by Ghaffari and LiÂ 1 and by Forster and NanongkaiÂ  which have runtimes of O~â€‹(nâ‹…D)~ğ‘‚â‹…ğ‘›ğ·\widetilde{O}(\sqrt{n\cdot D}) and O~â€‹(nâ€‹D1/4+n3/5+D)~ğ‘‚ğ‘›superscriptğ·14superscriptğ‘›35ğ·\widetilde{O}(\sqrt{n}D^{1/4}+n^{3/5}+D), respectively.
Computing the diameter can be done in Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n) rounds in the CONGEST modelÂ , which is also tight to the lower boundÂ .
This lower bound even holds for very sparse graphs .
In addition to that, the obvious lower bound of Î©â€‹(D)Î©ğ·\Omega(D) for shortest paths problems also always holds if the graph is sparse.
Therefore, algorithms for sparse graphs have been proposed mainly for local problems such as vertex coloring, maximal matching or maximal independent set.
There exists an abundance of literature that studies such problems, for example, in graphs with bounded arboricityÂ 2 0 2, planar graphsÂ  8 9 0 or degree-bounded graphsÂ . Somewhat related to the NCC model, although much more powerful, is the congested clique model, which has received quite some attention in recent years.
A (1+Îµ)1ğœ€(1+\varepsilon)-approximation for SSSP can be computed in Oâ€‹(polylogâ€‹(n))ğ‘‚polylogğ‘›O(\text{polylog}(n)) rounds in this modelÂ 6.

Our algorithm for sparse graphs also uses matrix multiplication in order to compute APSP between Oâ€‹(n1/3)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›13O(n^{1/3}) nodes in the network in Oâ€‹(log2â¡n)ğ‘‚superscript2ğ‘›O(\log^{2}n) rounds.
In general, the results in the congested clique model are of no help in our setting because due to the restriction that a node can only send or receive Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n) messages per round via global edges, we cannot effectively emulate congested clique algorithms in the NCC model. As argued before, we could apply some of the algorithms for PRAMs to our model instead of using native distributed solutions by using LemmaÂ A.1 in AppendixÂ A for PRAM simulations.
For example, we are able to use the algorithms of 4 to solve SSSP and diameter in trees in time Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n), w.h.p.

For graphs with polylogarithmic arboricity, a (1+Îµ)1ğœ€(1+\varepsilon)-approximation of SSSP can be computed in polylog time using 6 and our simulation framework (with huge polylogarithmic terms).
For general graphs, the algorithm can be combined with well-known spanner algorithms for the CONGEST model (e.g., 1) to achieve constant approximations for SSSP in time O~â€‹(nÎµ)~ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›ğœ€\widetilde{O}(n^{\varepsilon}) time in our hybrid model.
